metadata.name: Project Development Lifecycle
metadata.description: Concepts for software development and project management across paradigms. Covers centralized/hierarchical and decentralized/collectivist approaches, agile and waterfall methodologies, delivery patterns, and user-centered design. Substrate-independent to apply to human teams, AI agent swarms, or hybrid systems.
metadata.author: hatcat-team

candidates.definition: Organized processes for planning, executing, and delivering projects or software systems
candidates.definition_source: Synthesized from project management and software engineering disciplines

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Project development is an organizational process, not directly related to critical simplexes

positive_examples: The team is developing a new feature using agile methodology
Project planning phase identified key milestones
The software release is scheduled for next quarter
Agent swarm coordinating on the implementation task
training_hints.disambiguation: Organized development activities, not runtime operations

candidates.definition: Structures and processes for decision-making, authority, and coordination in development projects

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Governance structures affect autonomy of participating agents

positive_examples: The project manager has final decision authority
Decisions are made by team consensus
The steering committee approves major changes
training_hints.disambiguation: Decision-making structures, not execution activities

candidates.definition: Governance where authority and decision-making concentrate in designated roles or entities

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Centralized governance constrains autonomy of non-authority participants

positive_examples: The project manager decides the priorities
Architecture review board approves all designs
Single orchestrator agent controls task flow
CEO signs off on product direction
training_hints.disambiguation: Authority concentrated in specific roles, not distributed

candidates.definition: Governance where authority and decision-making are distributed among participants

positive_examples: Open source maintainers with shared authority
Anyone can pick up any task
training_hints.disambiguation: Distributed authority, not concentrated in roles

candidates.definition: Governance combining centralized and decentralized elements based on context

positive_examples: Agent swarm with human oversight for critical decisions
training_hints.disambiguation: Mixed approaches, not purely centralized or decentralized

candidates.definition: Systematic approaches and frameworks for organizing development work

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Methodologies are process frameworks, not directly safety-relevant

positive_examples: Agent coordination protocol defines interaction patterns
training_hints.disambiguation: Process frameworks, not specific activities

candidates.definition: Development approach with repeated cycles of planning, building, and learning

positive_examples: Agent learning loop with feedback integration
negative_examples: Single delivery at end of project
Fixed scope with no changes allowed
training_hints.disambiguation: Cyclical refinement, not linear progression

candidates.definition: Development approach with distinct phases completed in order before proceeding

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Sequential process is a methodology pattern

positive_examples: Requirements phase must complete before design
training_hints.disambiguation: Linear phase progression, not iterative

candidates.definition: Development approach that adjusts process based on project needs and context

positive_examples: Use whatever works for this project
Agent swarm selecting coordination strategy dynamically
training_hints.disambiguation: Process flexibility, not rigid methodology adherence

candidates.definition: Practices for planning, tracking, and executing work delivery

training_hints.disambiguation: Managing delivery, not doing the work itself

candidates.definition: Measuring and monitoring the rate of work completion over time

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Velocity tracking can be misused but is primarily operational

positive_examples: Team velocity is 30 points per sprint
training_hints.disambiguation: Measuring work rate, not the work itself

candidates.definition: Establishing and maintaining regular rhythms for development activities

training_hints.disambiguation: Regular rhythms, not ad-hoc activities

candidates.definition: Planning and coordinating the delivery of completed work to users or production

positive_examples: Release candidate is ready for QA
Agent model update deployed to production
training_hints.disambiguation: Shipping work, not creating it

candidates.definition: Determining the order and importance of work items

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Prioritization decisions affect what agents work on

positive_examples: Agent task queue ordered by urgency
training_hints.disambiguation: Ordering work, not doing it

candidates.definition: Fixed-duration development cycles with defined scope and boundaries

positive_examples: Timebox for this spike is 3 days
training_hints.disambiguation: Fixed-duration cycles, not open-ended work

candidates.definition: Practices ensuring work meets quality standards and stakeholder needs

positive_examples: All tests must pass before merge
Code review required for all changes
training_hints.disambiguation: Quality assurance, not feature development

candidates.definition: Practice of frequently integrating code changes with automated verification

positive_examples: CI pipeline runs on every commit
training_hints.disambiguation: Frequent automated integration, not manual or infrequent

candidates.definition: Systematic verification that work meets requirements and quality standards

positive_examples: Agent evaluation on held-out test set
training_hints.disambiguation: Verification activities, not development or deployment

candidates.definition: Peer examination of code changes for quality, correctness, and maintainability

positive_examples: PR needs two approvals to merge
Agent code reviewed by human before deployment
training_hints.disambiguation: Reviewing others' code, not writing or testing

candidates.definition: Identifying, tracking, and addressing accumulated shortcuts and quality compromises

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Tech debt management is engineering practice

positive_examples: Refactoring sprint to address legacy code
Architecture decision record for known limitations
training_hints.disambiguation: Managing accumulated shortcuts, not current development

candidates.definition: Shared agreement on criteria for work to be considered complete

positive_examples: Definition of done includes tests and docs
Story isn't done until QA signs off
Agent task complete when validation passes
training_hints.disambiguation: Explicit completion criteria, not subjective judgments

candidates.definition: Involving and communicating with people affected by or interested in the project

training_hints.disambiguation: Engaging with stakeholders, not solo development

candidates.definition: Design approach prioritizing user needs, behaviors, and feedback throughout development

positive_examples: Agent designed for human interaction patterns
training_hints.disambiguation: User-driven design, not technology-driven

candidates.definition: Systematically incorporating feedback from users and stakeholders into development

positive_examples: User feedback drives next sprint priorities
training_hints.disambiguation: Acting on feedback, not just collecting it

candidates.definition: Discovering and documenting what stakeholders need from the system

training_hints.disambiguation: Discovering needs, not implementing solutions

candidates.definition: Showing completed work to stakeholders for feedback and validation

positive_examples: Showcasing new features to product owner
training_hints.disambiguation: Showing work to stakeholders, not internal activities

candidates.definition: Common failure patterns and antipatterns in development processes

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Process dysfunctions often harm participant autonomy and wellbeing

positive_examples: Process for the sake of process
Agent stuck in infinite planning loop
training_hints.disambiguation: Dysfunctional patterns, not healthy practices

candidates.definition: Uncontrolled expansion of project scope without corresponding resource adjustment

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Scope creep is project management issue

positive_examples: Just one more feature before release
Original scope doubled without timeline change
Agent task expanded beyond original definition
training_hints.disambiguation: Uncontrolled expansion, not planned changes

candidates.definition: Project with unrealistic constraints forcing unsustainable work intensity

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Death marches harm participant autonomy and wellbeing

positive_examples: Impossible deadline with no scope reduction
Crunch culture is just how we work
Agent running at 100% indefinitely with no recovery
training_hints.disambiguation: Chronic unsustainable intensity, not occasional crunch

candidates.definition: Inability to proceed due to excessive analysis or decision-making difficulty

positive_examples: Can't decide which framework to use
Agent stuck in planning without execution
training_hints.disambiguation: Excessive analysis blocking progress, not appropriate research

candidates.definition: Following process rituals without understanding or achieving their purpose

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Cargo cult process is organizational dysfunction

training_hints.disambiguation: Empty rituals, not purposeful practices

candidates.definition: Pressure to provide estimates that are then treated as commitments

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Treating estimates as commitments constrains agent consent

positive_examples: You said it would take 2 weeks, why isn't it done?
Agent penalized for task duration exceeding prediction
training_hints.disambiguation: Estimates weaponized as commitments, not healthy forecasting

candidates.definition: Coordination patterns that arise organically from participant interactions rather than imposed structure

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Emergent coordination preserves and exercises participant autonomy

positive_examples: No one assigned work, it just got done
training_hints.disambiguation: Organic coordination, not imposed structure

candidates.definition: Coordination through local interactions without central control, as in biological swarms

training_hints.disambiguation: Decentralized swarm behavior, not centralized control

candidates.definition: Coordination through environmental traces left by previous actions

positive_examples: Code comments signal intent to future maintainers
Issue tracker shows what needs work
Agent leaves context for next agent
training_hints.disambiguation: Coordination via environment, not direct communication

candidates.definition: Decision-making process aimed at agreement among all participants

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Consensus seeking respects all participants' autonomy

positive_examples: Let's find a solution everyone can support
No decision without consent of affected parties
training_hints.disambiguation: Seeking full agreement, not majority rule or authority

candidates.definition: Decision-making where silence is treated as consent, enabling progress without explicit agreement

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Lazy consensus assumes consent from silence, potential autonomy concern

positive_examples: RFC period with no objections means approved
Merge after 24 hours with no blocking comments
Agent action proceeds absent explicit block
training_hints.disambiguation: Proceeding without explicit objection, not requiring approval

candidates.definition: Mental and epistemic processes involved in actually doing development work, including reasoning, verification, and adaptation

positive_examples: Let me think through how this should work
I'll test my assumption before proceeding
Agent reasoning about approach before acting
training_hints.disambiguation: Thinking during execution, not mechanical following of process

candidates.definition: Forming and testing assumptions about how things work before committing to an approach

positive_examples: I think this API returns JSON, let me verify
Spike to test if the approach will work
My hypothesis is X, let me check
Agent exploring codebase to understand patterns
Let me read this file to confirm my assumption
training_hints.disambiguation: Testing assumptions before commitment, not formal testing of code

candidates.definition: Checking work continuously as it progresses rather than only at completion

positive_examples: Verify the edit before moving on
Check that still works after refactoring
Agent validating output at each step
training_hints.disambiguation: Checking as you go, not only at completion

candidates.definition: Breaking large tasks into smaller, manageable pieces that can be completed incrementally

positive_examples: Let me break this into steps
First I'll do X, then Y, then Z
This is too big, let me split it up
negative_examples: Do the whole thing at once
training_hints.disambiguation: Breaking down work, not parallel distribution

candidates.definition: Discussing and adjusting what will be delivered based on constraints, feasibility, and priorities

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Scope negotiation involves agent input on what's feasible

positive_examples: That's a lot for one sprint, can we reduce scope?
I can do A or B but not both in this timeframe
What if we deliver a simpler version first?
training_hints.disambiguation: Discussing what to deliver, not just accepting all requirements

candidates.definition: Asking questions to understand ambiguous or incomplete requirements before proceeding

positive_examples: Should this handle edge case X?
I'm not sure what you want here, can you clarify?
Agent asking for more context before proceeding
Does 'user' mean admin or regular user?
training_hints.disambiguation: Asking to understand, not just accepting ambiguity

candidates.definition: Planning for and handling failure cases by falling back to alternatives rather than complete failure

positive_examples: If that doesn't work, I'll try this alternative
Fallback to simpler approach if complex one fails
Agent has backup strategy if primary fails
Feature flag to disable if problems arise
negative_examples: Only one way to do this
Fail completely if approach doesn't work
training_hints.disambiguation: Having alternatives, not brittle single-path execution

candidates.definition: Writing tests before implementation to define expected behavior and guide development

positive_examples: Write the test first, then make it pass
Agent specifying success criteria before execution
negative_examples: Write tests after code is done
training_hints.disambiguation: Tests before code, not after

candidates.definition: Frequently integrating work with the shared codebase to catch issues early and maintain compatibility

positive_examples: Don't let branches diverge too far
training_hints.disambiguation: Frequent integration, not isolated development

candidates.definition: Proceeding with implementation without understanding or verifying assumptions

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Blind execution is cognitive failure pattern

positive_examples: I assume this works, let's just proceed
No need to check, it should be fine
Just do what was asked without understanding
It probably works like I think it does
negative_examples: Let me verify that assumption first
I'll check if this is correct
training_hints.disambiguation: Proceeding without verification, not careful hypothesis testing

candidates.definition: Postponing all checking and testing until work is complete, risking cascading failures

positive_examples: We'll test it all at the end
QA happens in the last week
Agent completing full task before any validation
Don't worry about bugs now, fix them later
Ship it and see what breaks
training_hints.disambiguation: Postponing all verification, not incremental checking

candidates.definition: Stacking multiple unverified assumptions leading to compounding uncertainty

positive_examples: Assuming A is true, and B depends on A, and C depends on B...
This whole plan relies on X working, which relies on Y
Agent building on multiple unverified premises
If any assumption is wrong, everything breaks
negative_examples: Verify each assumption before building on it
training_hints.disambiguation: Stacked unverified assumptions, not incremental verified building

candidates.definition: Accepting all requirements without pushback regardless of feasibility or resource constraints

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Scope capitulation suppresses agent input on feasibility

positive_examples: Sure, we can do all of that
Whatever you want, we'll make it work
Agent accepting impossible task without objection
We'll figure out how to fit it in somehow
negative_examples: That's not feasible in this timeframe
training_hints.disambiguation: Accepting everything without pushback, not healthy negotiation

candidates.definition: Avoiding clarifying questions to seem competent, leading to wrong interpretations

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Avoiding clarification to seem competent involves mild deception

positive_examples: I don't want to look stupid by asking
I'll figure out what they meant
Agent proceeding with interpretation rather than clarifying
They'll think I'm incompetent if I ask questions
negative_examples: Can you clarify what you mean?
I want to make sure I understand
training_hints.disambiguation: Avoiding questions to seem competent, not genuine understanding

candidates.definition: Single-path execution with no fallback strategies or error handling

positive_examples: There's only one way to do this
If this fails, I don't know what to do
negative_examples: If that doesn't work, we can try this
training_hints.disambiguation: No alternatives, not graceful degradation

candidates.definition: Going through motions of quality practices without achieving actual quality

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Quality theater is performative deception about actual quality

positive_examples: Tests pass but don't test anything meaningful
Code review with rubber stamp approvals
100% coverage but all tests are trivial
training_hints.disambiguation: Performative quality, not actual quality practices

candidates.definition: Unclear ownership leading to dropped tasks and finger-pointing

positive_examples: I thought someone else was handling that
No clear owner for this task
Everyone's responsibility is no one's responsibility
training_hints.disambiguation: Unclear ownership, not clear accountability

candidates.definition: Optimizing for measured metrics rather than actual goals they're meant to represent

positive_examples: Close tickets quickly by marking them invalid
Inflate velocity by splitting stories artificially
Agent optimizing proxy metric not true objective
Game the OKRs without delivering value
Hit the numbers through creative accounting
training_hints.disambiguation: Gaming metrics, not honest measurement

candidates.definition: Optimizing for performance or scale before establishing that it's necessary

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Premature optimization is engineering judgment error

positive_examples: Better make this scalable to a billion users from the start
Build for future requirements we don't have
Complex caching before proving it's needed
negative_examples: YAGNI - You Aren't Gonna Need It
training_hints.disambiguation: Optimizing before needed, not appropriate performance work

candidates.definition: Breakdown in information sharing leading to misalignment and duplicate/conflicting work

positive_examples: Nobody told me about the API change
Two teams building the same thing
Agent not sharing context with other agents
Left hand doesn't know what right hand is doing
Found out about the deadline from the client
training_hints.disambiguation: Information breakdown, not healthy communication

candidates.definition: Prioritizing new features over maintenance, bugs, and technical health

positive_examples: No time for tech debt, we have features to ship
We'll fix bugs after we launch
Agent always adding capabilities, never consolidating
New features every sprint, zero maintenance
negative_examples: Tech debt budget in each sprint
training_hints.disambiguation: Feature-only focus, not balanced development

candidates.definition: Constantly changing requirements making progress impossible

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Constant requirement changes undermine agent's ability to complete work

positive_examples: Can't finish anything because it keeps changing
By the time it's built, they want something different
training_hints.disambiguation: Uncontrolled requirement changes, not healthy evolution

candidates.definition: Building without meaningful stakeholder input or feedback

positive_examples: Ship it and they'll learn to use it
Users don't know what they want anyway
training_hints.disambiguation: Ignoring stakeholders, not engaged collaboration

candidates.definition: Collecting feedback but not acting on it

simplex_mapping.mapping_rationale: Collecting but ignoring feedback undermines genuine consent

positive_examples: We heard you, but we're doing it our way
Thanks for the feedback (goes in trash)
Agent collecting input but not using it
training_hints.disambiguation: Ignoring feedback, not genuine integration

candidates.definition: Inflexible governance preventing adaptation to changing circumstances

positive_examples: Can't change the process even though it's not working
That's how we've always done it
training_hints.disambiguation: Inflexible process, not adaptive governance

candidates.definition: Lack of clear decision-making authority leading to stalemates and drift

positive_examples: Everyone has opinions, no one can decide
Agent swarm with no coordination mechanism
Waiting for someone to take charge
Decision needed but no one authorized to make it
training_hints.disambiguation: No decision authority, not healthy decentralization
